title: 109_s3899
content: The "Balanced Trade Restoration Act of 2006" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings related to trade. Since the 1990s, the US has faced record trade deficits, making it the largest debtor country. In 2005, the trade deficit was $767 billion, projected to increase in 2006. This could lead to a balance of payments crisis, impacting the US economy. GATT 1994 allows member countries to restrict trade quantities or values. The US has been facing record trade deficits since the 1990s, leading to concerns about its balance of payments. GATT 1994 permits member countries to restrict imports to safeguard their financial position. The US should gradually impose import restrictions to minimize disruption to its economy. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Balanced Trade Certificate" means a license to import goods into the US equal to or less than the certificate's value. "Department" refers to the Department of Commerce. "Oil or gas" includes goods classified under specific headings in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule. The term "Program" refers to the Balanced Trade Certificate Program established under section 4, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. Establishment of Balanced Trade Certificate Program within the International Trade Administration to create balance between imports and exports. Regulations will be issued for issuing, collecting, valuing, and trading Certificates. The Program established under section 4 will issue Certificates to exporters based on the appraised value of the exported goods. The value of the Certificate will be determined by the Secretary according to a system based on the appraised value declared on the shipper's export declaration. The Certificate's face value is based on a percentage of the appraised value of the exported goods, ranging from 140% in the first year of operation to 100% after the fourth year. Importers must submit a Certificate to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 90 days of importing goods into the United States, with a face value equal to or greater than the appraised value. The Secretary will establish a valuation method for imported goods, which may include the declared dollar value on the Entry Summary form. A system will be set up for the collection of these Certificates. Importers must submit a Certificate to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 90 days of importing goods into the United States, with a face value equal to or greater than the appraised value. Failure to do so will result in suspension from importing goods and a penalty of 3 times the appraised value of the imported goods. An exception is made for oil or gas during an adjustment period. Importers of oil or gas into the United States must submit a Certificate to the Secretary of Homeland Security within 90 days of importation, with a face value equal to or greater than the appraised value. This requirement does not apply to other goods, and failure to comply will result in penalties. If oil or gas is imported, a Certificate with a face value based on the appraised value is required within 90 days. The value varies from 60% to 100% depending on the year of importation. Management of Certificates involves the permanent removal of Certificates from circulation upon receipt by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Certificates issued are fully transferable and valid for 365 days from the date of issuance.
